template:
A Control Platform Based on IoT Technology

Control systems are everywhere - from the the thermostat in your house to nuclear power plants. Blinky-Lite is flexible and powerful enough to control anything from a blinking LED to a particle accelerator. What makes controls with Blinky-Lite different is:

  • Extremely reliable and robust control
    • Blinky-Lite is based on high performance but inexpensive IoT computing placed close to the devices you want to control.
  • Web Accessibility
    • Blinky-Lite applications are web-based giving you control from anywhere in the world.
  • Flexibility
    • Blinky-Lite is 100% open source for easy customization
  • Easy to implement
    • Blinky-Lite is designed for non-experts who have beginner knowledge in Javascript.

Ready to Go

Blinky-Lite comes with seven user web-based applications out of the box.

Easy to Use

Almost all of the code is written with Node-RED , a graphical programming enviroment.

The best way to understand the Blinky-Lite architecture is to build a simple full-stack demonstration system. The demonstration system will be based on a simple device that does the following:

  • Measures the distance to an nearby object and alarm if the object is too close
  • Measure the temperature
  • Measure the amount of light
  • Change the state of an LED from Off, Blinking, to On both remotely via a web app and locally via push button

All the drawings and source code for this tutorial can be found at https://github.com/Blinky-Lite/blinky-lite-demo .
The source code for the Control Box can be found at https://github.com/Blinky-Lite/blinky-lite-core .

name: device
template: A device can be any detector or actuator that has an electrical interface. Common devices are LEDs, switches, temperature probes, ultrasound transducers and receivers, etc. The IoT revolution has brought an explosion of such devices. Devices can also be more complicated such as an oscilloscope with a programmable interface (USB, ethernet, serial,...)

name: custom.css
deviceController
template:
The device controller conditions the signals to and from the device such as digitizing voltages, providing and digital and analog output signals, etc. The device controller is usually micro-controller such as an Arduino board. (However, many Blinky-Lite projects are done with the Teensy family of boards because they provide a very low cost but high performance platform.)

These microcontrollers are the swiss army knife of signal conditioning. They provide digitizing channels, digital status, pulse width modulation, and analog and digital outputs, but they are also very easy to use. The user communicates serially to the boards over a USB interface and the boards are programmed in C/C++ using the Arduino programming enviroment (IDE) . Many IoT vendors such as AdaFruit and SparkFun provide libraries for their devices along with step-by-step instructions on how to add these libraries to the Arduino IDE. The Arduino organization has provided an excellent set of tutorials with basic lessons on IoT electronics and how to program the controllers.

In addition to the USB serial interface, these microcontroller boards have a number of additional two-wire serial communication channels. Blinky-Lite uses one of these channels to communicate with the Device Message Adapter. As demonstrated in the Blinky-Lite Tutorial the communication uses binary buffers which provides simple, high speed and robust communication.

name: deviceMessageAdapter
template:
The device message adapter transmits and receives communication to and from the control box via MQTT messages as described in the Control Box description. The device message adapter than translates and transmits this information to the device controller over the serial port between the device controller and the device message adapter. There can be many device message adapters in a control system and in turn, a device message adapter can communicate with several device controllers.

This flexibility provides for local autonomous control. For example a single device message adapter could be located in a house to control the temperature of the house. The devices would be some type of thermometer and another device a switch to turn on and off the furnace. The device message adapter would regulate the temperature in the house based on a set point that was communicated to it from the control box. In turn the device message adapter could update the control box (and hence the user) on the status of the house. If communication between the device message adapter and the control box was to be interrupted, the device message adapter would continue to keep the house at the temperature it was last instructed.

name: controlBox
template:
The control box is the heart of the Blinky-Lite architecture. The typical Blinky-Lite control box is a Raspberry Pi 3B computer. The Raspberry Pi 3B is a low cost, high performance computer that has ethernet, Wifi, and bluetooth communications. The Blinky-Lite tutorial provides instructions on how to setup the Raspberry Pi or disk images that have the Blinky-Lite already installed.

The control box has four major components:

  • MQTT broker {{{payload.controlbox.mqttBroker}}}
  • MongoDB Database {{{payload.controlbox.mongoDB}}}
  • Core app server {{{payload.controlbox.coreAppServer}}}
  • Custom app server {{{payload.controlbox.customAppServer}}}

name: userInterface
template: Applications for control and monitoring of the devices must be available to the user. Blinky-Lite uses web applications for these type of applications. Modern web browsers provide powerful plotting and graphical environments. A web applications is a much better way to control deployment for these applications. The web applications communicate with the server using websockets which allow real-time communication among different clients connected to a server.

name: custom.css
setupRpi.setupDI
template:
On Linux desktop computer, download the latest Raspberry Pi image at: https://downloads.raspberrypi.org/raspbian_latest The downloaded file will have a name like YYYY-MM-DD-raspbian-stretch.zip Where YYYY-MM-DD is the year, month, and date of the release. Change directory to the location of the downloaded file and unzip it:

unzip YYYY-MM-DD-raspbian-stretch.zip

Before you insert an SD card into your computer identify the names of the drives on your computer by typing:

df -h

You will see something similar to the screenshot below:

Now, insert an 8GB (or greater) SD card into your computer. Type:

df -h

to determine the name of the SD card

In this example the name of the SD card is mmcblk0 (p1 is the partition). Copy the disk image to the SD card

sudo dd if=YYYY-MM-DD-raspbian-stretch.img of=/dev/SD-CARD-NAME bs=1M

Where in this example SD-CARD-NAME is mmcblk0. Once the disk copy is complete, eject the disk and re-insert the disk. You should see two partitions show up on your linux desktop. The RaspberryPi image now comes with SSH disabled. To enable it, open the boot partition of the sd card and create a file named ssh. From a linux terminal on your desktop computer enter:

sudo nano /media/$USER/boot/ssh

Type a couple of characters and save (cntrl-x). For the Raspberry Pi Zero , there is no ethernet connection so you need to give it the information to connect to your wireless network. Edit the wpa_supplicant.conf file on the rootfs partition of the sd card. From a linux terminal on your desktop computer enter:

sudo nano /media/$USER/rootfs/etc/wpa_supplicant/wpa_supplicant.conf

Add the following lines to the file where country-abbrev is your contry abbreviation (for example in Sweden it is SE), your-wireless-ssid is your wireless ssid and your-wireless-ssid-passwordis your wireless ssid password

country=country-abbrev

network={
    ssid="your-wireless-ssid "
    psk="your-wireless-ssid-password"
    key_mgmt=WPA-PSK
}

and save (cntrl-x).

name: setupRpi.connectRpi
template:
Eject the sd card and place it into the Raspberry-Pi. Connect the Raspberry Pi with an ethernet cable to your router and then power up the raspberry pi. Open a linux terminal and ssh into the RaspberryPi:

ssh pi@raspberrypi.local

The default password for the Raspberry-Pi is raspberry . We will want to change this immediately. Now configure the Raspberry-Pi by running the configuration program:

sudo raspi-config

The raspi-config program looks as below:

  • First change the password - Menu Iterm 1
  • Under Menu Item 2, change the hostname. Do not set up the wifi, we will do that later
  • Under Item 5, Enable both SSH (P2) and VNC (P3). We will need VNC later
  • Under Item 7, set the screen resolution (for the VNC server) - Choice A5. I prefer DMT Mode 35 1280x1024 60Hz 5:4
  • Under Item 7, Expand the file system - Choice A1
  • Under Item 5, Serial Port (P6) select No for Would you like a login shell to be accessible over serial?Select Yes for Would you like the serial port hardware to be enabled?

You should get an screen lookin as the following:

Using the arrow keys navigate to Finish to exit the configuration program and reboot the RaspberryPi

On your linux Desktop, download the RealVNC Viewer at https://www.realvnc.com/en/connect/download/viewer/linux/

We will now connect to the RaspberryPi desktop. It is easy to finish the rest of the configuration from the RaspberryPi Desktop and the VNC Viewer will allow you to run programs such as the Arduino programing environment on the RaspberryPi.

  • Open the VNC viewer and make a New Connection under the File menu. Change the VNC server to: hostname.local:5900 where hostname is what you entered in Item 2 of the raspi-config program.
  • Close the new connection dialog and double click on your new connection in the VNC Viewer window.
  • The VNC viewer should connect to the RaspberryPi. At first it will warn you of an identity check. Just click continue.
  • Next you will be asked for a username and password. The username is pi. The password is the password you entered in Item 2 of the raspi-config program.

You should see a window as below:

The wireless connection can be setup by clicking on the Up-Down arrow icon in the upper righthand corner of the desktop. A nice GUI version of the configuration program can be found under the Preferences sub-menu of Raspberry menu.

Open the GUI raspi-config program and under the Localisation tab, set the Locale, Timezone, and Keyboard. The RaspberryPi will have to be booted for these changes to take effect.

name: setupRpi.setupNodejs
template:
The RaspberryPi comes with very old versions of node.js and npm installed. In this section we will update node.js and npm. From your linux desktop, ssh into the RaspberryPi

ssh pi@hostname.local

Where hostname is what you entered in Item 2 of the raspi-config program. Check the version of node:

node -v

As of 2018-04-18 release, the RaspberryPi ships with node.js at v4.8.2. To upgrade, check the hardware on your RaspberryPi.

uname -a

A RaspberryPi 3 runs an ARM7 processor while a RaspberryPi Zero runs an ARM6 processor. For easier cleanup later, on the ssh session you are running to connect to the RaspberryPi, change the directory to the Download directory:

cd ~/Downloads

In a browser go to the nodejs download page at: https://nodejs.org/en/download/ The Node.js download page will look as below:

Find the linux binary distribution that matches your RaspberryPi hardware (most likely ARMv7). ' Copy the link location and in the ssh terminal type:

wget https://nodejs.org/dist/vX.YY.Z/node-vX.YY.Z-linux-armv7l.tar.xz

Where vX.YY.Z is current release of node.js. Then, unzip the file:

tar -xf node-vX.YY.Z -linux-armv7l.tar.xz

Navigate into the unzipped directory:

cd node-vX.YY.Z-linux-armv7l

And copy the files to the /usr/ directory by:

sudo cp -R * /usr/

Now check the version of node.js by:

node -v

and:

npm -v

You should see a node version that matches vX.YY.Z and an npm version greater than 5.5. You can now delete all the items in the RaspberryPi download directory:

rm -rf ~/Downloads/*

name: setupRpi.setupMQTT
template:
Note: Only the Blinky-Lite Core Raspberry Pi needs to have a MQTT broker installed. Blinky-Lite device message adapters do not require a MQTT broker. Their are many open source MQTT brokers available but Blinky-Lite will use Mosquitto supported by the Eclipse Foundation. Open a terminal session into your Raspberry-Pi either through an ssh session from your Linux desktop RealVNC Connection. Once you have a terminal session running on your Raspberry-Pi, install Mosquitto by typing:

sudo apt-get install mosquitto

To run tests on your Raspberry, using mosquitto_sub clients (to subscribe),mosquitto_pub (to post messages) and mosquitto_passwd (to set up users and passwords) enter:

sudo apt-get install mosquitto-clients

Then edit the mosquitto configuration file

sudo nano /etc/mosquitto/mosquitto.conf

by addingto the bottom of the file:

allow_anonymous false
password_file /etc/mosquitto/pwfile

and save and exit (Ctrl-x). Now setup the password for the MQTT broker:

sudo mosquitto_passwd -c /etc/mosquitto/pwfile broker-name

I usually choose the hostname of the Raspberry-Pi as the broker name. The program will ask you for the a password for your broker. After you have chosen the password, reboot your Raspberry-Pi:

sudo reboot

The Mosquitto MQTT broker should start on boot. When the Raspberry-Pi comes back up, login and check that the MQTT broker is running by typing at the terminal:

ps -aux | grep mosquitto

You should see an output looking something like:

mosquit+ 302 0.3 1.0 8228 4500 ? S 07:41 0:00 /usr/sbin/mosquitto -c /etc/mosquitto/mosquitto.conf

But the process numbers will be different. Now test the MQTT broker by subscribing to a topic:

mosquitto_sub -h 127.0.0.1 -t chit/chat -u broker-name -P broker-password

where:

  • -h is the IP address of the broker (which is 127.0.0.1 right now since we are testing the example locally on the broker).
  • -t is the topic you wish to subscribe to (chit/chat in this example)
  • -u is the broker name you chose for the MQTT broker previously
  • -P is the password of the MQTT broker

The program will now wait for messages. In another terminal window, login to the Raspberry-Pi and enter:

mosquitto_pub -h 127.0.0.1 -t chit/chat -m "Hi There" -u broker-name -P broker-password

Where -m is the message you would like to send to the broker (“Hi There” in this example). You should see in the terminal running mosquitto_sub the message echoed. Congratulations! You now have a function MQTT broker. You can exit the mosquitto_sub program by typing ctrl-c

name: setupRpi.setupMongoDB
template:
Note: Only the Blinky-Lite Core Raspberry Pi needs to have MongoDB installed. Blinky-Lite device message adapters do not require MongoDB.

Open a terminal session into your Raspberry-Pi either through an ssh session from your Linux desktop RealVNC Connection. Once you have a terminal session running on your Raspberry-Pi, install MongoDB by typing:

sudo apt-get install mongodb-server
sudo service mongod start
sudo reboot

MongoDB should start on boot. When the Raspberry-Pi comes back up, login and check that MongoDB is running by typing at the terminal:

ps -aux | grep mongodb

You should see an output looking something like:

mongodb 276 4.6 5.3 817796 50804 ? Ssl May10 603:57 /usr/bin/mongod --config /etc/mongodb.conf

But the process numbers and date will be different.

name: controlbox.mqttBroker
template:
MQTT is a very popular IoT communication protocol that was invented by IBM in 1999 for connecting oil pipelines over satellite connection and is now an open source platform. MQTT is designed to be reliable, data-agnostic, and lightweight and is quickly becoming the protocol of choice for IoT.

MQTT messages consist of a topic and payload. The topic is a hierarchical character string with the hierarchy defined by forward slashes. This hierarchy allows for the use of wildcards. For example, let’s say that there are many buildings providing temperature readings to a MQTT broker. Some of these buildings could be homes, others are factories; all with different locations. By putting the building type and address in the topic, one could subscribe to temperature readings only homes in a given area.

The MQTT payload can be anything from a text string, to a number to an image. The user just has to know ahead of time what the format of the data will be. Blinky-Lite uses JSON strings which is a very compact and readable way of writing data.

Users keep an open connection to the MQTT broker and subscribe or publish to topics. If a user is subscribing to given topic and another user publishes a payload to that topic than the first user will receive a notification that a new payload is available for the topic. This eliminates the need for polling and provides a buffer to keep a device from being overloaded with too many requests.

For example, assume a single device is measuring a temperature but there are over a 1000 users that want to know this temperature. In a conventional distributed system, each user would make a request to the device for the temperature value. If each user wants to know the temperature as a function of time, then each user must poll the device periodically for the temperature value. With so many users, this could easily overwhelm the device providing the temperature reading.

With Blinky-Lite and MQTT, the device publishes the temperature to the broker when the device is ready (i.e. the temperature has changed or at a certain rate). The users are connected to the MQTT broker and subscribe to the temperature topic. When the topic is updated, the users get a notification that it has been updated and retrieve the data from the broker - not the device.

Blinky-Lite uses the Eclipse Mosquitto MQTT broker which is an open source broker.

name: controlbox.mongoDB
template:
All control systems need to store data. To provide flexibility for the type of data to be stored, Blinky lite uses MongoDB which is an open-source, non-relational database. Another advantage of MongoDB is that queries and data are in JSON objects which is a natural fit to the javascript programming environment of Blinky-Lite.

Blinky-Lite has two databases, the Devices database and the Archiver database. The Devices database contains a single record for each device in the control system. The Archiver database has many entries for a single device. A Device is considered to be a unique MQTT topic. Any topic is possible but this would make developing user applications problematic. Blinky-Lite specifies the device topic have the following seven fields:

sys01/sys02/sys03/sys04/device/attr/prop

An example topic would be:

R3/rfroom/02/diag/oo/beamCurrent/reading

Stored in the record are device attributes such as alarm limits, archiving rate, and the latest data value along with timestamp for the device. Blinky-Lite currently supports two types of data structures, scalar and vector. However the flexible nature of MongoDB will permit many other types of data structures such as images.

The Blinky-Lite core application server subscribes to all MQTT topics in a Blinky-Lite control system. When a new message is published, the data is stored in the Devices database. The core application server then looks to see when the device data was last written to the Archiver database and decides to write a new record to the Archiver database based on the archiving rate for the device.

name: controlbox.coreAppServer
template:
The data collected by the database must eventually be consumed by the user. Blinky-Lite provides seven web-based applications for the end user that access the MongoDB database.

  • Scalar Device Plotter
    Plots a number of scalar devices in real time
  • Scalar Device Archive Plotter
    Retrieves and plots the history over a specified time period for a number of scalar devices. Data can also be downloaded into a csv file.
  • Vector Device Plotter
    Retrieves and plots the history over a specified time period for a number of scalar devices. Data can also be downloaded into a csv file.
  • Vector Device Archive Plotter
    Retrieves and plots the history over a specified time period for a single vector device. The display provides a number of different views. Data can also be downloaded into a csv file.
  • Alarm Scanner
    Displays devices that are outside their alarm limits. The alarms can be filtered by device name. Also audible alarming can be enabled.
  • Device Viewer
    The current values of a number of scalar devices are displayed. It is also possible to set the device values and then have the message broadcasted.
  • Device Editor
    A tool for creating new devices or modifying existing devices.

name: controlbox.customAppServer
template: In case the applications available in the Core app server are not sufficient for the user needs, a custom app server can be implemented. The custom app server is encased in a Node-Red application.

name: demoCircuit
template: You can download the the circuit diagram, breadboard layout, PCB layout, parts list, at the Blinky-Lite-Demo Github repository in the circuit-board-design folder of the archived device-controller zip file

name: deviceController
template: The demo circuit uses the Teensy LC as the device controller. The Teensy LC is programmed with the Arduino IDE . Instructions on how to setup the Arduino IDE for programming the Teensy is at https://www.pjrc.com/teensy/teensyduino.html . The sketch (or program) to be loaded on the Teensy LC is in the micro-controller-code folder of the archived device-controller zip file . You can also view the file online at the demo github repository.

name: deviceMessageAdapter
template:
The demo circuit uses the Raspberry Pi Zero W as the device message adapter. We will program the device message adapter with the Node-RED programming enviroment. Instructions on how to setup the Raspberry Pi Zero W with the correct version of Node.js is outlined at the bottom of this tutorial. Use

blinky-lite-demo-dma-green

as the hostname. Once the Raspberry Pi Zero W has been setup, login into the home directory of the Raspberry Pi Zero W

ssh pi@blinky-lite-demo-dma-green.local

and enter the following commands:

wget https://github.com/Blinky-Lite/blinky-lite-demo/archive/device-message-adapter.zip
unzip device-message-adapter.zip
mv blinky-lite-demo-device-message-adapter blinky-lite-demo
rm device-message-adapter.zip
cd blinky-lite-demo
npm install

Now setup the enviromental variables that will be used in the Node-RED flow. Use the nano editor to edit the .env file

nano .env

and paste the following into the file. (Make sure there is no carriage return at the end of the file).

ARCHIVERTOPIC=archiver\/blinky-lite\/demo\/breadboard\/green\/
MQTTCLIENTID=blinky-lite-demo-green-dma
MQTTSERVERIP=blinky-lite-controlbox-demo.local
MQTTUSERNAME=blinky-lite-controlbox-demo
MQTTPASSWORD=blinky-lite
NODEREDCONFIGSECRET=a-secret-key

Save and exit the nano editor by entering Ctrl-x on the keyboard.

Now, to start the device message adapter on boot edit the /etc/rc.local file

sudo nano /etc/rc.local

Right before the line containing exit 0, enter

/home/pi/blinky-lite-demo/run-blinky-lite.sh /home/pi/blinky-lite-demo > /home/pi/blinky-lite-demo.log &

Save and exit the nano editor by entering Ctrl-x on the keyboard and reboot the Raspberry Pi.

sudo reboot

Once the computer is rebooted, the Raspberry Pi Zero W should be serving the device message adapter Node-RED flow. Point web browser at: http://blinky-lite-demo-dma-green.local:1880/admin You will see the Node-RED splash screen. The username is admin and the password is blinky-lite. Of course the username and password can be changed in the settings.js file in the blinky-lite-demo directory. Once the user name and password are entered, the device message adapter Node-RED flow is displayed and can be customized as the user desires. Please note that if the MQTT broker on the Control Box has not been setup, green flags will not appear next to the magenta colored MQTT nodes on the device message adapter flows.

name: controlBox
template:
The Control Box in this tutorial runs on a Raspberry Pi 3B+ . Similar to the device message adapter, all code on the Control Box is written as Node-RED flows. Instructions on how to setup the Raspberry Pi 3B+ with the correct version of Node.js is outlined at the bottom of this tutorial. For the Control Box, the Mosquitto MQTT broker and MongoDB database are required to be installed. Use:

blinky-lite-controlbox-demo as the hostname,
blinky-lite-controlbox-demo as the MQTT username,
and blinky-lite as the MQTT password.

These can be customized later on. Once the Raspberry Pi 3B+ has been setup, login into the home directory of the Raspberry Pi 3B+:

ssh pi@blinky-lite-controlbox-demo.local

and enter the MongoDB application to configure the database:

mongo

you will see a > line prompt. Enter at the prompt:

use blinky-lite

you get message: switched to db blinky-lite. Enter at the prompt:

db.createCollection("devices");

you get message: { "ok" : 1 }. Enter at the prompt:

db.createCollection("archiver");

you get message: { "ok" : 1 }. Enter at the prompt:

exit

you get message: bye

From the /home/pi directory of the Control Box, enter the following commands:

wget https://github.com/Blinky-Lite/blinky-lite-core/archive/master.zip
unzip master.zip
mv blinky-lite-core-master blinky-lite-core
rm master.zip
cd blinky-lite-core
npm install

Now setup the enviromental variables that will be used in the Node-RED flow. Use the nano editor to edit the .env file

nano .env

and paste the following into the file. (Make sure there is no carriage return at the end of the file).

MONGODBIP=127.0.0.1
MQTTCLIENTID=blinky-lite-core-demo
MQTTSERVERIP=127.0.0.1
MQTTUSERNAME=blinky-lite-controlbox-demo
MQTTPASSWORD=blinky-lite
NODEREDCONFIGSECRET=a-secret-key

Save and exit the nano editor by entering Ctrl-x on the keyboard.

Now, to start the Control Box on boot edit the /etc/rc.local file

sudo nano /etc/rc.local

Right before the line containing exit 0, enter

sleep 10
/home/pi/blinky-lite-core/run-blinky-lite.sh /home/pi/blinky-lite-core > /home/pi/blinky-lite-core.log &

Save and exit the nano editor by entering Ctrl-x on the keyboard and reboot the Raspberry Pi. The 10 second sleep is to let MongoDB boot but is not necessary.

sudo reboot

Once the computer is rebooted, the Control Box should be serving Blinky-Lite core applications. Point web browser at: http://blinky-lite-controlbox-demo.local:11880/ . You will see the Blinky-Lite Core application page. However, there are no device definitions entered into the database. You must use the Device Editor application to define devices.

As of this writing, the Blinky-Lite Device Editor does not have a batch or spreadsheet upload for defining devices. The properties of each device must be entered separately. Use the table below to define the device properties for the demo circuit. The below table shows properties for two device message adapters - one green and the other red

name: customApp
template:
If the core applications do not serve all of the users needs, then a custom application server can be installed on the Control Box. To install the demo custom application server login into the home directory of the Control Box:

ssh pi@blinky-lite-controlbox-demo.local

From the /home/pi directory of the Control Box, enter the following commands:

wget https://github.com/Blinky-Lite/blinky-lite-demo/archive/user-interface.zip
unzip user-interface.zip
mv blinky-lite-demo-user-interface blinky-lite-demo-ui
rm user-interface.zip
cd blinky-lite-demo-ui
npm install

Now setup the enviromental variables that will be used in the Node-RED flow. Use the nano editor to edit the .env file

nano .env

and paste the following into the file. (Make sure there is no carriage return at the end of the file).

MONGODBIP=127.0.0.1
MQTTCLIENTID=blinky-lite-demo-ui
MQTTSERVERIP=127.0.0.1
MQTTUSERNAME=blinky-lite-controlbox-demo
MQTTPASSWORD=blinky-lite
APPPORT=1880
COREPORT=11880
NODEREDCONFIGSECRET=a-secret-key

Save and exit the nano editor by entering Ctrl-x on the keyboard.

Now, to start the custom application server on boot edit the /etc/rc.local file

sudo nano /etc/rc.local

Right before the line containing exit 0, enter

sleep 10
/home/pi/blinky-lite-demo-ui/run-blinky-lite.sh /home/pi/blinky-lite-demo-ui > /home/pi/blinky-lite-demo-ui.log &

Save and exit the nano editor by entering Ctrl-x on the keyboard and reboot the Raspberry Pi. The 10 second sleep is to let core application server boot but is not necessary.

sudo reboot

Once the computer is rebooted, the custom application server should be serving the custom applications. Point web browser at: http://blinky-lite-controlbox-demo.local:1880/ . You will see the custom application launch page. From this page you can reach the custom applications as well as the core applications.

It is a bit clumsy to have the default Node-RED port number in the address of the custom application server. This port can be routed to the default browser port 80 by the following steps.

sudo iptables -t nat -A PREROUTING -p tcp --dport 80 -j REDIRECT --to-port 1880
sudo iptables -t nat -I OUTPUT -p tcp -d 127.0.0.1 --dport 80 -j REDIRECT --to-ports 1880
sudo sh -c "iptables-save > /etc/iptables.ipv4.nat"

Now edit the /etc/rc.local file:

sudo nano /etc/rc.local

Right before the line containing exit 0, enter

iptables-restore < /etc/iptables.ipv4.nat

Save and exit the nano editor by entering Ctrl-x on the keyboard and reboot the Raspberry Pi.

sudo reboot

Once the computer is rebooted, the custom application server should be serving on port 80. Point web browser at: http://blinky-lite-controlbox-demo.local/

Blinky-Lite provides seven web-based applications out of the box.

Scalar Device Plotter

Plots a number of scalar devices in real time

Scalar Device Archive Plotter

Retrieves and plots the history over a specified time period for a number of scalar devices. Data can also be downloaded into a csv file.

Vector Device Plotter

Plots a single vector device in real time.
The display provides a number of different views.

Vector Device Archive Plotter

Retrieves and plots the history over a specified time period for a single vector device.
The display provides a number of different views.
Data can also be downloaded into a csv file.

Alarm Scanner

Displays devices that are outside their alarm limits. The alarms can be filtered by device name. Also audible alarming can be enabled.

Device Viewer

The current values of a number of scalar devices are displayed. It is also possible to set the device values and then have the message broadcasted.

Device Editor

A tool for creating new devices or modifying existing devices.
